Main observation targets: Gray-matter atrophy, white-matter lesions, and whole-brain atrophy
The main findings: Decreased gray-matter density in frontal lobes, hippocampus, and cingulate cortex;lower cortical thickness in multimodal integration regions, such as frontotemporal regions

Main observation targets: Identify the intrinsic spontaneous brain neural activity during resting state to investigate the brain function, such as amplitude of low-frequency fluctuations (ALFF) and default-mode network (DMN)
The main findings: Significant decrease in ALFF in the left parahippocampal gyrus (PHG) and an increased ALFF in right superior orbital frontal gyrus (SOFG);increased functional connectivity (FC) between the right insular region and the right SOFG and between the right calcarine cortex and the left PHG;significant differences in functional alterations of the DMN
Impaired CVR may contribute to the progression of white matter disease

Main observation targets: Determine the integrity and lesions of white-matter tracts, such as fractional anisotropy (FA) and mean diffusivity (MD)
The main findings: Dysfunction of white matter integrity;DTI parameters (especially FA) could serve as a potent imaging indicator for detecting the invisible alteration of white matter integrity

Main observation targets: Evaluate the permeability and integrity of blood-brain barrier (BBB); quantitative tissue perfusion such as blood volume, mean transit time, mean transit time
The main findings: Higher BBB permeability was associated with higher LA burden and cognitive decline

Main observation targets: Identify changes in cerebral metabolites such as the ratios of N-acetyl aspartate (NAA)/choline (Cho) and NAA/creatine (Cr)
The main findings: Metabolic changes suggested that MRS can be explored as a marker for cognitive dysfunction in patients with LA
